Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: A public protest begins to escalate, with tension rising between opposing groups
Story: I was on duty when the call came in—a protest downtown was turning volatile. As a police officer, I was expected to keep the peace, to step in and enforce the law if things got out of hand. My radio crackled with updates, and I could hear the rising shouts from the crowd as I approached. Just then, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my mom. She rarely called during the day unless something was wrong. I hesitated, torn. As a daughter, I was supposed to check in, to be there for my parents, especially since Dad’s health had been shaky lately. I could almost hear Mom’s voice, needing reassurance, needing me. But the protest was escalating, and my team was counting on me to help manage the chaos. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, feeling the weight of both uniforms I wore—one as a daughter, the other as an officer—each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore.
